showme.pack.title: Example: Transformation of a Line Segment
showme.pack.caption: Transformation of a Line Segment

statement.para: In the picture below the line segment [a,b] on the left gets transformed into the red curve on the right.

figure.caption: Transforming a line segment into a curve.

statement.para: To fit this intuitive process into the mathematical formalism of functions, we do the following:

li.para: We take the interval [a,b] in \RNr as the domain of the transforming function f.
The plane \RNr[2] on the right is the target of f.
The curve on the right is the transformed line segment. This is also called the image of f.

statement.para: The function f\from [a,b]\to \RNr[2] transforms [a,b] into the curve on the right. Note that the image of f need not be equal to the target \RNr[2]. Note also that the end point a of [a,b] gets transformed into the end point f(a) of the curve on the right, and that the end point b of [a,b] gets transformed into the end point f(b) of the curve.
